Description:
Folkestone Repair Cafe at Sunflower House is a real community collective: we are simply a group of people who like preserving special things with sentimental value, avoiding waste, fixing whatever we can fix!

You‚Äôll find a warm welcome with free refreshments, a helpful team of repairers and some useful advice.
We are also planning a toolkit loan system to help you do stuff at home.

Get in touch if you can help ‚Äì and we can add you to our listing of good people!

Folke Art is an arts and health project in its second year, run by Community Art Kent CIC in partnership with Sunflower House. Folke Art is a free weekly community art class run out of the new Sunflower House community room on the Bayle and is for adults aged 55+.

Folke Art provides a much-needed accessible art classes to adults in Folkestone, providing long term health and wellbeing benefits to those that take part, connecting adults living in Folkestone to artists living and working in the town as well as local creative businesses.  

Folke Art Outcomes for participants:

¬∑        Improved Mental Health

¬∑        Reduction in loneliness

¬∑        Increased sense of belonging

¬∑        Improved access to the arts

¬∑        Learning new skills

Folke Art Aims

¬∑        Provide free art classes to Adults in Folkestone

¬∑        Enable local artists to deliver workshops within the setting

¬∑        Link creatives based around the Creative Quarter to the town

¬∑        Provide supportive art classes that increase wellbeing.

¬∑        Signpost participants to other activities across the town

¬∑        Safeguard adults and provide a safe and supportive creative environment

The Folke Art project is currently open to new participants, if you would like to attend please email communityartkent@gmail.com

Folke Art, Follow on Folke Art and Folke Art CT19 are funded by Kent County Council, NHS Kent & Medway, Folkestone & Hythe District CouncIl, Folkestone Town Council, Skinners Foundation CT, Colyer Ferguson CT, Kent Community Foundation and South Eastern Railway.

Organisation(s): Action on Homelessness in Folkestone;Sunflower House

Description:
Kent Community Pantry is part of the Children and Families charity group.

KCP aims is to make healthy and nutritious food affordable!

Our service will provide you with either 10 or 20 products, depending on the membership type you choose.  We aim to provide you with a wide selection of fresh fruit, veg, bakery products, dairy, meat, hygiene and non-food products subject to availability.

This is an amazing service and membership starts from as little as ¬£17 a month!

Loose Ends was set up to provide a simple drop-in ‚Äì the name explains itself well. Visitors vary in age from early twenties through to their eighties. The age-old recipe of chatting with another human being over tea and biscuits is linked with referral to other activities in the Sunflower House portfolio. Our aim is to tackle social isolation in a practical way, advice on tap relating to health and wellbeing, support groups, help and basic hope. Hope is sometimes the difference between survival and tragedy.

Sunflower Coffee House / Warm Welcome Session

Description:
Little Free Library's mission is to be a catalyst for building community, inspiring readers, and expanding book access for all through a global network of volunteer-led Little Free Library book-exchange boxes.

There are multiple Little Free Libraries maintained by individuals around Folkestone & Hythe.

The Folkestone Nepalese Community (FNC), in partnership with the Folkestone & Hythe District Council, organises a fortnightly community litter picking event to promote a cleaner and greener environment.

üóì When: Every second Sunday

üïô Time: 10:00 AM

üìç Location: FNC Centre or a designated local area

This regular initiative brings together volunteers of all ages to support local cleanliness and environmental care. Gloves, bags, and equipment are provided‚Äîjust bring your enthusiasm!

Join us in making a positive difference in our community!

The Folkestone Nepalese Community (FNC) is proud to deliver the Warm Safe Hub project as part of the UK Shared Prosperity Fund (UKSPF) Community Hub: Cost of Living Support and Warm Space initiative, supported by Folkestone & Hythe District Council.

Our Warm Safe Hub offers a welcoming, comfortable, and inclusive space where residents can come together during the colder months. It‚Äôs more than just a warm room ‚Äî it‚Äôs a place to connect, share, relax, and receive support.

Visitors can enjoy refreshments, tea and coffee, warmth, and friendly company, while also accessing practical help such as food and fuel vouchers, warm clothing, and advice on local welfare and wellbeing services.

This project reflects FNC‚Äôs ongoing commitment to support community wellbeing, reduce isolation, and help local residents cope with the cost of living pressures across Folkestone and the wider district.

Location(s): The Message Hub - Tontine Street;The Message Hub - Black Bull Road
Description: The Message Hubs were created by Strange Cargo in collaboration with the local community in East Folkestone, creating space at busy intersections for locals to post community notices and event posters, and have since become a well-used community resource.

Beacon Plus have a dedicated caf√© which is run by our learners in the centre of Folkestone, giving our learners the opportunity to cook, bake bread and serve customers.  They are also responsible for the business side of the caf√© including profit and loss and purchasing stock.

The caf√© is open to the public and is available for private functions or community groups. Nearly all of the food available is freshly prepared and cooked on the premises.

The caf√© team also hold regular market days at the Bouverie Place Shopping centre in Folkestone where they sell seasonal cakes and bread freshly baked on the day.

You can find us at the church hall at Our Lady Help of Christians, 41a Guildhall Street, Folkestone CT20 1EF

e-mail us at events@beacon-plus.org.uk if you would like to find out more about what we can offer, including catering for external events.

We are open Monday, Tuesday, Thursday and Friday 9.30am-2.30pm.

Our Family Support Service is available during term time and offers both one-to-one support and in-person group sessions. Run by our experienced team and dedicated volunteers, our relaxed SEND support groups give parents and carers the opportunity to connect, share experiences, and access advice in a supportive and welcoming space.
Lending Library offering sensory toys and equipment for Family Support service users to try before they buy.

Description:
We are Folkestone Community Fridge CIC (FCF), a non-profit organisation tackling food waste in our local area. Run by a dedicated team of 40+ volunteers we collect perfectly good food that would otherwise be wasted and offer it to our community instead. 

FCF is free to use for everyone and continues to be a way of supplementing the weekly shop for many who are struggling with the daily cost of living.

Description: We don‚Äôt think anyone in our community should have to face going hungry. That‚Äôs why we provide three days‚Äô nutritionally balanced emergency food and support to local people who are referred to us in crisis. We are part of a nationwide network of foodbanks, supported by The Trussell Trust, working to combat poverty and hunger across the UK.

The Rainbow Centre values our community and believes that everybody should have access to good food. These things are combined in our Pantries, a service we run in partnership with Your Local Pantry.

Our Pantries are about giving people dignity, choice and hope until they can get back on their feet financially.

Description: The Homeless Support Service is committed to supporting people from the Folkestone and Hythe district who find themselves either homeless or at risk of becoming so. The Centre‚Äôs commitment is based on a Christian response to social injustice.

FoodStop is a volunteer-run mobile food service providing sandwiches & snacks in Folkestone every week of the year.  The food is prepared locally by our team of volunteers and given to those within our community who are homeless or in extreme poverty.

Description:
Money First Aid is a partnership of well-known local non-profit organisations helping local people who are struggling with their finances to regain control.

Once a client has been signed up for the service, a Volunteer Mentor will work with them to understand their main worries or anxieties and support them to prepare for their meeting with a qualified Money Adviser from Citizens Advice.  The Adviser will work with the client and the Volunteer Mentor to develop suitable debt options.

Our Family Contact Centre provides a safe, friendly and neutral place for children of separated families to spend time with one or both parents, or other family members, whilst enjoying toys, games and refreshments.

The Folkestone Churches Winter Shelter project was established in 2009 by Churches Together Folkestone and other local interests, having witnessed the hardships facing homeless people locally. For the last fifteen years, the Folkestone Rainbow Centre has overseen the operation of the shelter project.

Freecycle offers an online space to give awat unwanted items and make sure they find a new home. Folkestone's local group is very active and full of great freebies.

Olio is an app that allows people to find and give away unwanted food. There is an active network of Olio collectors in Folkestone & Hythe who collect food from supermarkets and make it available for anyone for free.

Our annual summer parade brings thousands together in a joyful display of pride, solidarity, and visibility. For young people, newcomers, and long-standing residents alike, the parade is a powerful reminder that they belong here.
We offer flexible support services, with both full-day and half-day options tailored to your needs.

Born at the WOW festival and founded and run voluntarily by Katy Lockey and Catherine Sangster, FWF has been running free feminist events in Folkestone since 2015. To date, this has included over 100 regular gatherings with speakers, 4 IWD festivals, online workshops during COVID-19, book groups, walks, craft nights, and many more casual social events.
Repair items that would normally be thrown away, bikes, clothes, hoovers, toys etc Payment by donation. Refreshments available while items are being fixed.

The Wild About Sandgate project aims to raise awareness of all the public green spaces in Sandgate, including the sea and shoreline by educating and enthusing people about everything that lives and grows in them. Alongside this, the project will  support and encourage people to take positive action by making micro nature reserves in their own gardens, balconies or windowsills and lend the odd hand  to volunteer groups like  the  Sandgate Sprucers, Sandgate Environmental Action and Sandgate Community Garden

Fancy some exercise or an activity with your children or grandchildren that will also help your village? Then why not do some litter picking to help keep our village, sea and beaches litter free. Sandgate Parish Council have provided  community litter picking kits, which are now available to borrow from outside of the library. Inside the chest are litter pickers, hoops, bags and gloves. There are 20 pickers in total so it is perfect for a group activity.

We‚Äôre also proud to offer a growing collection of film-based photographic equipment, perfect for anyone wanting to explore analog photography without the investment. Whether you‚Äôre a seasoned film shooter or a curious beginner, we‚Äôve got you covered.

Are you feeling distressed, frightened, overwhelmed, or that things are too much for you? Don‚Äôt know where to turn to get mental health support? Are your usual sources of support closed for the night?

Folkestone Safe Haven offers out-of-hours mental health support to anyone aged 18+ in the Kent area.

This is a walk-in service - there's no need to be referred by your GP or Care Coordinator. The Folkestone Safe Haven offers a welcoming, safe, comfortable, non-judgmental and non-clinical environment, sometimes known as 'crisis cafes'. At the safe haven, we will be able to provide information and emotional support if you are in crisis or feel you are heading towards a crisis situation.

To get involved in South Kent Mind‚Äôs activities and services, you will be required to complete a wellbeing check-in with a member of our Wellbeing Team.

These are a 50-minute discussion on how you are currently coping with your mental health and what support would be best for you.

Once a wellbeing check-in has been completed, you will be registered with South Kent Mind and will be able to participate in our activities and services. Wellbeing check-ins are available by contacting us via any of the following ways:

We aim to offer a supportive environment to carers as well as some people living with mental illness. We offer a relaxed and friendly space where people can share their problems and learn about organisations and support services that may be able to help them.

Individual Placement & Support (IPS) employment support helps people with any kind of mental illness to find and sustain paid employment. We do not provide support ro access volunteering or training.

The support is rapid with job searching starting within four weeks, even if a person has been off work for years.

This is individualised, person-centred, trauma-informed and time unlimited.

OnePlanet Cats: Emotional wellbeing, Employment access, Safe & comfortable housing for all
Description:
Are your feelings or worries affecting your health, relationships, work or day-to-day life? You‚Äôre not alone. Thousands of people in the UK experience mental health issues each year.

If you‚Äôre aged 17+ and live in Kent or Medway, our network of voluntary organisations and charities can help you:

- Better manage your mental health and general wellbeing
- Gain confidence and meet new people
- Get advice for money, debt or benefit-related issues
- Get support for housing concerns
- Access free therapy and counselling-type services
- Find work, volunteering and education opportunities
- Join local activities and support groups run by people with similar experiences.

If you identify as a young LGBTQ+ person we have a range of support you can access.

Our meet-ups are safe spaces for young people who are LGBTQ+ or think they might be LGBTQ+.

You can meet new people who share some of the same feelings and experiences as you, socialise, and talk in a safe and non-judgemental setting.

It‚Äôs also a great way to meet the BeYou team who can give you additional support if you need it.

Meet-ups are held weekly. Some take place in person, others are online.

If you identify as a young LGBTQ+ person we have a range of support you can access.

Everyone, at times, can find things a little challenging and difficult to manage. You may want to chat with an experienced LGBTQ+ youth support worker.

Sessions are between 30 mins to 1 hour, we do what works for you. They may take place at a youth centre, online or in the community.

Folkestone Women‚Äôs Forum is a feminist organization with community, collaboration, and connection at its core. We hold discussions of our interests, work, passions, and experiences. We also support and publicize other events under the FWF umbrella ‚Äì meet-ups, book discussions, walks, games nights, meals ‚Äì and encourage you to get involved in organizing these.

The Drop Off will be manned by volunteers who can also advise on general recycling, promote the work of the Hythe Environmental Group and oversee the Drop Off.

Hythe Hops community hop garden is part of the national Grow Beer movement, We are a voluntary, non-profit group; our members grow hops in their back gardens, allotments, gardens, community gardens and also public spaces.

Description: CAP is a highly reputable and nationally recognised charity that provides practical, professional support to people struggling with debt. SKCC operates a CAP centre for the Shepway area. Under the leadership of Centre Manager Angela Burnett and a dedicated team of trained volunteers, the centre has supported many clients since opening in early 2007. Through CAP's structured debt-management process and ongoing support, clients have experienced significant positive change in their financial circumstances and overall wellbeing.

Little Treasures Toddler Group runs on Monday mornings (during term time) from 9.30 - 11.30 a.m. at The Cornerstone Centre, Castle Hill Avenue, Folkestone.

There is tea & cake for the grown ups and lots of fun activities for the little ones.
